channel.title: Interleaved RSS Feed
channel.description: This is an interleaved feed of the most recent entries from each RSS source, skipping any feeds with errors.

item.title: Central Texas Could See Damaging Winds and ‘Very Large Hail’ on Tuesday
item.description: Forecasters said there was a moderate risk of severe weather for Tuesday after powerful storms swept through large sections of the country over the Memorial Day weekend.

item.title: Middle East Crisis: 3 European Countries to Formally Recognize Palestinian Statehood
Bill Gates said he wished he learned this lesson from Warren Buffett sooner: The power of an 'intentionally light' calendar
item.description: "In hindsight, it’s a lesson I could have learned a lot sooner had I taken more peeks at Warren Buffett’s intentionally light calendar."

item.title: China’s Role in Ukraine
item.description: Russia has been able to keep paying for the war, despite sanctions. How? U.S. officials point to Beijing.

item.title: World Leaders Denounce Deadly Strike in Rafah
item.description: They called for an investigation into the attack, which Gazan authorities say killed 45 people, and intensified the pressure for Israel to end its military campaign in southern Gaza.

item.title: While American companies go quiet on climate change, Europeans keep banging the drum
item.description: One-pager: Concerns over culture wars and ESG investment backlash are stronger factors in the U.S. than Europe, which may lead to further divergence on net zero trajectories.

item.title: What We Know About the Papua New Guinea Landslide
item.description: Nearly five days after the disaster hit a remote section of the country, officials have started evacuating residents. But the scale of the death toll remains uncertain.

item.title: Why Lawmakers Are Brawling and People Are Protesting in Taiwan
item.description: Supporters of President Lai Ching-te are protesting legislative amendments introduced by the opposition that would limit his authority.

item.title: 'Rational' monetary policies are back, says Turkey's finance chief, as he seeks to stabilize inflation-ridden economy
item.description: Turkey had kept interest rates low amid soaring inflation, against conventional wisdom, leading investors to desert its bond market.

item.title: The Alitos and Their Flags
item.description: The saga of a Supreme Court justice, his wife and two symbols adopted by people campaigning to overturn the result of the 2020 election.

item.title: What We Know About the Papua New Guinea Landslide
item.description: Nearly five days after the disaster hit a remote section of the country, officials have started evacuating residents. But the scale of the death toll remains uncertain.

item.title: American company tells Mexico president that his $385m offer to buy its Caribbean property for ecotourism 'substantially undervalues' its crocodile-filled quarries
item.description: Mexican President Andrés Manuel López Obrador has threatened to expropriate the property, claiming the pits it has dug to extract crushed limestone have damaged the area's fragile system of underground rivers and caves.

item.title: OpenAI Says It Has Begun Training a New Flagship A.I. Model
item.description: The advanced A.I. system would succeed GPT-4, which powers ChatGPT. The company has also created a new safety committee to address A.I.’s risks.

item.title: Carbon Offsets, a Much-Criticized Climate Tool, Get Federal Guidelines
item.description: The new principles aim to define ‘high-integrity’ offsets amid concerns that current practices often don’t cut greenhouse gas emissions as claimed.

item.title: Wisconsin law that banned collective bargaining for most public employees back in court
item.description: The court is controlled 4-3 by liberals, a flip from when it upheld the law a decade ago under 5-2 conservative control.
